article.title: Covenant-breaker
article.paragraph: lead rewriteAugust 2014Use dmy datesJuly 2012Bah' sidebarACovenant-breakeror the act ofCovenant-breakingis a term used byBah' FaithBah'sto refer to a particular form of what some might call "heresy".Actually it refers to disunity: "The specific mission of Bah'u'llh relates to world unity. Since it would be impossible for the Bah' Faith to unite the world if it were itself disunited, the role of the covenant as the guarantor of the unity of the Bah' community becomes inextricably linked with the goal of world unity: "It is evident that the axis of oneness of the world of humanity is the power of the Covenant and nothing else." (TDP 49, cf GPB 239, SWA 208-9).Covenant, The, and Covenant-breakerBeing declared a Covenant-breaker is done by the head of the Faith — which since 1963 refers to the elected nine-memberUniversal House of Justice, the governing body of the Bah's. Bah's avoid association with them, even if the Covenant-breaker is a family member. The authority to declare a Bah' a Covenant-breaker resides solely with the head of the Bah' Faith.
article.heading: Definition
article.paragraph: Covenant-breaking does not refer to attacks from non-Bah's or former Baha'is. Rather, it is in reference to internal campaigns of opposition where the Covenant-breaker is challenging the unity of the Faith, causing internal division, or by claiming or supporting an alternate succession of authority or administrative structure. The central purpose of the covenant is to prevent schism and dissension.In a letter to an individual dated 23 March 1975, the Universal House of Justice wrote:quoteWhen a person declares his acceptance of Bahá'u'lláh as a Manifestation of God he becomes a party to the Covenant and accepts the totality of His Revelation. If he then turns round and attacks Bahá'u'lláh or the Central Institution of the Faith he violates the Covenant. If this happens every effort is made to help that person to see the illogicality and error of his actions, but if he persists he must, in accordance with the instructions of Bahá'u'lláh Himself, be shunned as a Covenant-breaker.

The term 'Covenant-breaker' or, in Arabic 'naqid al-mithaq' [pl. Naqidu 'l-mithaq], was first used by`Abdu'l-Bahto describe the partisans of his brotherMrz Muhammad `Al, who challenged his leadership. In `Abdu'l-Bah'sWill and Testament of `Abdu'l-BahWill and Testament, He appointedShoghi Effendias theGuardianof the religion and called for the eventual election of theUniversal House of Justice, and defined in the same manner opposition to these two institutions as Covenant-Breaking. `Abdu'l-Bah advised all Bah's to shun anyone opposing the Covenant: "...one of the greatest and most fundamental principles of the Cause of God is to shun and avoid entirely the Covenant-breakers, for they will utterly destroy the Cause of God, exterminate His Law and render of no account all efforts exerted in the past."The Will And Testament of Abdul-Bah,p 20
article.heading: Categorization
Included categories of people
article.paragraph: While most Covenant-breakers are involved in schismatic groups, that is not always the case. For example, a Bah' who refuses to follow guidance on treatment of Covenant-breakers is at risk of being named one. One articleThe Covenant, and Covenant-breaker, by Moojan Momenoriginally written for the Bah' Encyclopedia, characterized Covenant-breakers that have emerged in the course of Bah' history as belonging to one of four categories:

list.listitem: Leadership challenge: These are persons who dispute the authority and legitimacy of the head of the religion and advance claims either for themselves or for another. The main examples of these areMrz Muhammad `AlandMason RemeyCharles Mason Remey.

Dissidence: Those who actively disagree with the policies and actions of the head of the faith without, however, advancing an alternative claim for leadership. This group consisted mostly of opponents of the Bah' administration such asRuth White (Bah' author)Ruth WhiteandMirza Ahmad Sohrab.

Disobedience: Those who disobey certain direct instructions from the head of the religion. Mostly the instruction in question is to cease to associate with a Covenant-breaker. Examples of this type include most of the descendants of `Abdu'l-Bah during Shoghi Effendi's time.
Apostates who maliciously attack the Bah' Faith. Examples includevrihandNk.

article.heading: Excluded categories of people
article.paragraph: Shoghi Effendi wrote to the National Spiritual Assembly of Canada in 1957:quotePeople who have withdrawn from the Cause because they no longer feel that they can support its Teachings and Institutions sincerely, are not Covenant-breakers -- they are non-Bahá'ís and should just be treated as such. Only those who ally themselves actively with known enemies of the Faith who are Covenant-breakers, and who attack the Faith in the same spirit as these people, can be considered, themselves, to be Covenant-breakers.Shoghi Effendi, Messages to Canada, p. 64

Beyond this, many other relationships to the Bah' Faith exist, both positive and negative. Covenant-breaking does not apply to most of them. The following is a partial list of those who could not rightly be termed Covenant-breakers:

list.listitem: Members of other religions or no religion--with or without any particular relationship to the Bah' Faith.
Bah's who simply leave the religion. (see above)

Bah's who, in the estimation of the head of the religion have insufficiently understood the nature of the covenant from the start. These are sometimes "disenrolled" and are considered to have never actually been Bah's, given their fundamental diversion from this core Bah' doctrine.

article.heading: Bbs
article.paragraph: Bbsare generally regarded as another religion altogether. Since Covenant-breaking presumes that one has submitted oneself to a covenant and then broken it, and Bbs never recognized or swore allegiance to Bah'u'llh, they are not Covenant-breakers.

Followers ofSubh-i-Azal, Bah'u'llh's half-brother who tried to poison him, engaged in active opposition to Bah's, and Shoghi Effendi did inform Bah's that they should avoid contact with his descendants, writing that "No intelligent and loyal Baha'i would associate with a descendant of Azal, if he traced the slightest breath of criticism of our Faith, in any aspect, from that person. In fact these people should be strenuously avoided as having an inherited spiritual disease -- the disease of Covenant-breaking!".Shoghi Effendi, From letter dated 9 December 1948 to an individual believer
article.heading: Covenant-Breaking in Shoghi Effendi's immediate family
article.paragraph: Through the influence ofBah'u'llh's familyBahiyyih Khanum, the eldest daughter ofBah'u'llh, everyone in the household initially rallied aroundShoghi Effendiafter the death of`Abdu'l-Bah. For several years his brother Husayn and several cousins served him as secretaries. The only ones publicly opposing him were Mirza Muhammad-Ali and his followers, who were declared Covenant-breakers by `Abdu'l-Bah. Contrary to `Abdu'l-Bah's specific instruction, certain family members established illicit links with those declared Covenant-breakers by `Abdu'l-Bah. After Bahiyyih Khanum died in 1932, Shoghi Effendi's eldest sister--Ruhangiz --married a son ofBah'u'llh's familySiyyid Ali Afnan. Bah'u'llh's son-in-law was, thus, a long-standing enemy of `Abdu'l-Bah (who had declared him a Covenant-breaker.) Through Ruhangiz's efforts, Shoghi Effendi's other sister and his cousin Thurayya also married sons of Siyyid Ali Afnan. Presumably being faced with a choice between shunning their disobedient family members and being themselves disobedient to `Abdu'l-Bah and Shoghi Effendi, his cousins, aunts and uncles chose the latter.
article.heading: Ruhi Afnan
article.paragraph: After years of silence on these developments, cables sent byShoghi Effendion 2 November 1941 provide background to developments among family members. Ruhi Afnan, Shoghi Effendi's cousin through`Abdu'l-Bah's daughter Tuba:

list.listitem: "Ruhi's sister married Covenant-breaker Faydi whose mother joined and supported arch-enemy Muhammad-`Ali and whose father `Abdu'l-Bah denounced openly and repeatedly as His deadly enemy. Ruhi's family concurred. Inform all believers all manner communication excommunicated family forbidden."

article.paragraph: Then in a 1950 cable:

list.listitem: "Inform friends that Ruhi, his mother, with Ruha, his aunt, and their families, not content with years of disobedience and unworthy conduct, are now showing open defiance." (Citadel of Faith, p. 87)

article.paragraph: And in 1953:

list.listitem: "Treacherous Ruhi Afnan, not content with previous disobedience, correspondence withMirza Ahmad Sohrab, contact with old Covenant-breakers, sale, in conjunction with other members of family, of sacred property purchased by Founder of Faith, and allowing his sister to marry son of `Abdu'l-Bah's enemy, is now openly lecturing on Bah' movement, claiming to be its exponent and is misrepresenting the teachings and deliberately causing confusion in minds of authorities and the local population. Inform National Assemblies." (Messages to the Bah' World - 1950-1957, p. 48)

article.paragraph: Later, Ruhi was presented with a copy of Sohrab's book about his excommunication:

list.listitem: " under ordinary circumstances he would have been very much elated, and therefore thankful to see someone make such records of his services to the Cause, but that the references to the Guardian and the Administration changed his attitude completely. He did not wish to be defended; he felt that he must suffer in silence and be true to the Masters last will and testament. Then Ruhi Effendi referred to Ahmad as being in the same plight as himself, but reacting differently. He thought this very regrettable." [p. 281]From Gaslight to Dawn 10-19

article.heading: Munib Shahid
article.paragraph: Concerning Munib Shahid, Shoghi Effendi's cousin through `Abdu'l-Bah's daughter Ruha, Shoghi Effendi sent the following cable to the Bah' world in November 1944:

list.listitem: "Monib Shahid, grandson of both `Abdu'l-Bah and theNrayn-i-NayyiraynKing of Martyrs, married according to the Moslem rites the daughter of a political exile who is nephew of theGrand Mufti of Jerusalem. This treacherous act of alliance with enemies of the Faith merits condemnation of entire Bah' world." (Bah' News, No. 172)

article.heading: Husayn
article.paragraph: Concerning his own brother Husayn, Shoghi Effendi sent the following cable to the Bah' world in April 1945:

list.listitem: "My faithless brother Husayn, after long period of dishonourable conduct, has abandoned the Master's home to consort with his sister and other Covenant-breakers." (Bah' News, No. 174)

article.heading: Riaz
article.paragraph: Concerning his own brother Riaz, the following cable was sent in December 1951:

list.listitem: "With feeling profound concern, grief, indignation, am compelled disclose Bah' world recent developments Holy Land furnishing further incontestable proof relationship established old and new Covenant-breakers demonstrating increasing boldness, marked, tragic decline in character and spiritual condition grandchildren `Abdu'l-Bah. Their shameful attitude and conduct receiving approbation their elders. Evidences multiplying attesting Ruhi's increasing rebelliousness, efforts exerted my eldest sister pave way fourth alliance members family Siyyid Ali involving marriage his granddaughter with Ruha's son and personal contact recently established my own treacherous, despicable brother Riaz with Majdi'd-Din, redoubtable enemy Faith, former henchman Muhammad-'Ali, Archbreaker Bah'u'llh's Covenant. Convey information all National Assemblies." (Messages to the Bah' World - 1950-1957, p. 16)

article.heading: Mehrangiz
article.paragraph: He dispatched a cable concerning his younger sister in December 1941:

list.listitem: "Sister Mehrangis [Mehrangiz] followed example Ruhi's [Ruhi] sister Justice demands announce believers her expulsion." (Unfolding Destiny, p. 149)

article.heading: Resultant groups
article.paragraph: mainBahá'í divisionsMost of the groups regarded by the larger group of Bah's as Covenant-breakers originated in the claims of Charles Mason Remey to the Guardianship in 1960. TheWill and Testament of `Abdu'l-Bahstates that Guardians should belineal primogeniturelineal descendantsofBah'u'llh, that each Guardian must select his successor during his lifetime, and that the nineHands of the Cause of Godpermanently stationed in theholy landmust approve the appointment by majority vote. Bah's interpret lineal descendency to mean physical familial relation to Bah'u'llh, of which Mason Remey was not.

Almost all of Bah's accepted the determination of theHands of the Causethat upon the death of Shoghi Effendi, he died "without having appointed his successor". There was an absence of a valid descendant of Bah'u'llh who could qualify under the terms of `Abdu'l-Bah's will. Later theUniversal House of Justice, initially elected in 1963, made a ruling on the subject that it was not possible for another Guardian to be appointed.

In 1960 Remey, a Hand of the Cause himself, retracted his earlier position, and claimed to have been coerced. He claimed to be the successor to Shoghi Effendi. He and the small number of people who followed him were expelled from the Faith by the Hands of the Cause. Those close to Remey claimed that he went senile in old age, and by the time of his death he was largely abandoned, with his most prominent followers fighting amongst themselves for leadership. [Citation needed.]

The largest group of the remaining followers of Remey, members of the so called "Orthodox Bah' Faith", believe that legitimate authority passed from Shoghi Effendi to Mason Remey to Joel Marangella. [Citation needed.] They, therefore, regard the Universal House of Justice in Haifa, Israel to be illegitimate, and its members and followers to be Covenant-breakers. [Citation needed.]

The present descendants of expelled members of Bah'u'llh's family have not specifically been declared Covenant-breakers, though they mostly do not associate themselves with the Bah' religion. [Citation needed.] A small group of Bah's in Northern New Mexico believe that these descendants are eligible for appointment to the Guardianship and are waiting for such a direct descendant of Bah'u'llh to arise as the rightful Guardian.

There is also a small group in Montana, originally formed around the personality of Leland Jensen, who claimed a status higher than that of the Guardian. His failed apocalyptic predictions and unsuccessful efforts to reestablish the Guardianship and the administration were apparent by his death in 1996. A dispute among Jensen's followers over the identity of the Guardian resulted in another division in 2001.[Citation needed.]
